channel.title: Pentagon Plan to Regrow Limbs: Phase One, Complete
channel.description:
The first phase of the Pentagon's plan to regrow soldiers' limbs is complete; scientists managed to turn human skin into the equivalent of a blastema — a mass of undifferentiated cells that can develop into new body parts. Now, researchers are on to phase two: turning that cellular glop into a square inch of honest-to-goodness muscle tissue. The Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) just got a one-year, $570,000 grant from Darpa, the Pentagon's blue-sky research arm, to grow the new tissues. "The goal is to genuinely replace a muscle that's lost," biotechnology professor Raymond Page tells Danger Room. "I appreciate that's a very aggressive goal." And it's only one part in a larger, even more ambitious Darpa program, Restorative Injury Repair, that aims to "fully restore the function of complex tissue (muscle, nerves, skin, etc.) after traumatic injury on the battlefield." Muscles are, of course, famous for their ability to regenerate; they're broken down and rebuilt with every gym workout. But when too much of a muscle is lost — either from injury or illness — "instead of the regenerative response, you get scarring," Page says. He's hoping to get a different result, by carefully growing fresh muscle, outside the body. Step one will be trying to get those undifferentiated cells to turn into something like muscle cells. That means making sure the cells have myosin and actin — two proteins that are key to forming the cellular cytoskeleton, and to building muscle filaments. Then, Page and his team will try to get those cells to form around a scaffolding of tiny threads, made of biomaterial. Exactly what will be in thread, Page isn't quite sure — maybe collagens, maybe fibrinogens. It's one of many mysteries to unravel, as his team tries to grow body parts from scratch.
sauce: http://blog.wired.com/defense/2009/03/darpa-muscle-re.html Hope it gets far..

item.title: Pentagon Plan to Regrow Limbs: Phase One, Complete
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I found this most interesting. It seems like it’d be a very expensive operation though, doesn’t it?

[quote=“jme, post:12, topic:269787”][quote author=pk3r john link=topic=356088.msg2855223#msg2855223 date=1246806768]

One problem. If they can make muscle like that, they can make a super human which could go hulk on all of us and kill everyone.

[/quote]

No super human could take a bullet to the brain

As for stem cells, take them from the umbilical cord. I can’t understand how people have a moral problem with stem cells.[/quote]

People don’t like it because it encourages abortion, and many religions are against that.

Read full topic
item.source: Pentagon Plan to Regrow Limbs: Phase One, Complete

@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

jme:

As for stem cells, take them from the umbilical cord. I can’t understand how people have a moral problem with stem cells.

IIRC, they also take them from fetuses in the first days it’s there. That’s why religious idiots are against it. They believe that a fetus that is a few days ‘old’ is a living being.

Stem Cell research didnt “kill young children” either
[/quote]Meh, I don’t know much about stem cells… But if I recall they took cells from a fetus? Can’t that cause harm to the fetus itself?[/quote]

They took them from aborted fetuses if I remember correctly. They could also collect them from umbilical cords.
